title: Atomic Swaps CLI User Guide
description: The command line guide for Atomic Swaps, i.e., exchanging two different cryptocurrencies from separate blockchains in a trust-less and decentralized manner.

children.value: Atomic Swaps are a peer-to-peer marketplace built directly into your Beam wallet that allows users to swap Beam for another cryptocurrency. Trade your Beam for Bitcoin, Ehtereum, LiteCoin, DOGE, and more!
DO NOT USE THIS HIGHLY ADVANCED FEATURE FOR LARGE SUMS OF MONEY
For Electrum we support only Legacy type seeds and SSL connection
Perform an Atomic Swap with LiteCoin
Using Alice and Bob as an example, we will go over how to perform an Atomic Swap of Alice's Beam for Bob's LiteCoin (LTC).
Bob and Alice must configure their LTC node to allow RPC access either through the command line or edit their
(for this example, we will use standard node and RPC ports).
Alice and Bob can run a full LTC node by entering the following command:
The nodes must be synced to the current blockchain height before an Atomic Swap can occur.

Users can check their LTC balance by entering the following command:
To configure the Atomic Swap settings, enter the following command:
Each cryptocurrency has its own transaction fees
Avoid transaction jamming or failure by double-checking the

is denominated in "photons." 1 LTC = 1000000 photons, which is denominated in Beams while also offering fixed fee rates, regardless of transaction size.
{% endhint %}
Both parties can initiate the Atomic Swap by entering the following command:
is used when the other party (Alice) swaps Beam for a different cryptocurrency.
Bob must copy the swap token and forward it to Alice. After, Bob can enter the
Alice can accept the swap by entering the following command:
If Alice accepts the swap, it will create a swap transaction, and the LTC and Beam will lock on Bob's blockchain.
Each blockchain has its own block generation time
After six blocks, Bob will redeem Alice's Beam coins, revealing a secret transaction code and completing Bob's portion of the Atomic Swap. ‌
Alice will redeem Bob's LTCs using the secret transaction code revealed to her, completing the Atomic Swap.
Bob and Alice can return to their respective Beam and LTC wallets to confirm the details of the Atomic Swap.
Perform an Atomic Swap with Bitcoin
Using Alice and Bob as an example, we will go over how to perform an Atomic Swap of Alice's Beam coins for Bob's Bitcoin (BTC).
Bob and Alice must configure their BTC node to allow RPC access either through the command line or edit their config files according to the

Bob must copy the swap token and forward it to Alice. After, Bob can enter the
Alice can accept the swap by entering the following command:
If Alice accepts the swap, it will create a swap transaction, and the BTC and Beam will lock on Bob's blockchain.
Each blockchain has its own block generation time
After six blocks, Bob will redeem Alice's Beam coins, revealing a secret transaction code and completing Bob's portion of the Atomic Swap. ‌
Alice will redeem Bob's BTCs using the secret transaction code revealed to her, completing the Atomic Swap.
Bob and Alice can return to their respective Beam and BTC wallets to confirm the details of the Atomic Swap.

title: Confidential Assets
description: Confidential Assets (known as "Tokens" in the Beam ecosystem) are new assets created on the Beam blockchain with native support via Beam nodes, wallets, and DAPPS. New tokens created on the Beam blockchain offer the same privacy and security as Beam coins

children.value: Confidential Assets (known as "Tokens" in the Beam ecosystem) are new assets created on the Beam blockchain with native support via Beam nodes, wallets, and DAPPS. New tokens created on the Beam blockchain offer the same privacy and security as Beam coins
Use the command line to register a Confidential Asset.
will limit several asset operations for 1440 blocks (24 hours).

An asset will "lock" when its total emission reaches or leaves 0. Lock periods prevent an asset owner from altering an asset during rollback, guaranteeing that a Receiver will receive the expected asset.
All incoming asset transactions will return an
error code if CA is not enabled
flag to perform any CA transactions.
The fixed fee for asset registration is 3000 Beam

Users must register all CAs on-chain Before before usage.
{% endhint %}
To register a new asset, enter the following command:

props.code: ./beam-wallet asset_reg -n <node address and port> --asset_meta <meta keys> –f <fee in Groth> --enable_assets <flag for assets>

children.value: ./beam-wallet asset_reg -n <node address and port> --asset_meta <meta keys> –f <fee in Groth> --enable_assets <flag for assets>
How it will look in your wallet logs
The wallet log should resemble the following:

The owner of a Confidential Asset can unregister the asset from the blockchain. Asset emission must be zero and not in a lock period. The owner will pay a regular transaction fee and receive their initial asset registration fee of 3000 Beam.
To unregister an asset, enter the following command:

props.code: ./beam-wallet asset_unreg --asset_id <your asset id> -n <node address and port> –f <fee in Groth> --enable_assets <flag for assets>

children.value: ./beam-wallet asset_unreg --asset_id <your asset id> -n <node address and port> –f <fee in Groth> --enable_assets <flag for assets>

props.code: ./beam-wallet asset_unreg --asset_meta <meta keys> -n <node address and port> –f <fee in Groth>  --enable_assets <flag for assets>

children.value: ./beam-wallet asset_unreg --asset_meta <meta keys> -n <node address and port> –f <fee in Groth>  --enable_assets <flag for assets>

New asset registration starts the total emission at zero. The owner must issue asset coins before performing transactions. Asset emissions are free, and the asset owner can mints coins as they deem necessary.
To issue an asset, enter following command:

props.code: ./beam-wallet issue --asset_id <your asset id> -n <node address and port> -a <amount in Beams> -f <fee in Groth> --enable_assets <flag for assets>

children.value: ./beam-wallet issue --asset_id <your asset id> -n <node address and port> -a <amount in Beams> -f <fee in Groth> --enable_assets <flag for assets>

props.code: ./beam-wallet issue --asset_meta <meta keys> -n <node address and port> -a <amount in Beams> –f <fee in Groth> --enable_assets <flag for assets>

children.value: ./beam-wallet issue --asset_meta <meta keys> -n <node address and port> -a <amount in Beams> –f <fee in Groth> --enable_assets <flag for assets>

title: Laser Beam CLI User Guide
description: Laser Beam is a direct link (or "channel") between two Beam wallets that allows instant payments. Laser Beam is not available on Desktop or Mobile wallets.

children.value: To perform an instant transaction, both parties must submit Beam coins to an open Laser Channel. The coins will remain locked while the channel is open, only committing the channel's last state to the blockchain when Laser Channel is closed, thus, completing the payment.
Both the Sender and Receiver must agree on the

to perform an instant payment.
{% endhint %}
Opening a Laser Channel between two wallets
Using Alice and Bob as an example, let's go over setting up a direct channel between two wallets.
To create a channel, Alice enters the following command:

props.code: $ ./beam-wallet laser --laser_receive --laser_my_locked_amount <amount in beam> --laser_remote_locked_amount <amount in beam> --laser_fee <amount in groth>

children.value: $ ./beam-wallet laser --laser_receive --laser_my_locked_amount <amount in beam> --laser_remote_locked_amount <amount in beam> --laser_fee <amount in groth>
The output will generate a channel address that Alice can send to Bob, it should be similar to the following:
Using the channel address he received from Alice, Bob will insert the channel address right after

props.code: $ ./beam-wallet laser --laser_open --laser_address <address> --laser_my_locked_amount <amount in beam> --laser_remote_locked_amount <amount in beam> --laser_fee <amount in groth>

children.value: $ ./beam-wallet laser --laser_open --laser_address <address> --laser_my_locked_amount <amount in beam> --laser_remote_locked_amount <amount in beam> --laser_fee <amount in groth>
If Bob incorrectly entered the values previous command, then Alice will receive an “
How it will look in Alice's wallet
How it will look in Bob's wallet
Now that Alice and Bob have established a Laser Channel between their wallets, they can send direct payments
, Bob will confirm that the channel ID is open by entering the following command:

props.code: $ ./beam-wallet laser --laser_listen [channel id 1,channel id 2, ... channel id N]

children.value: $ ./beam-wallet laser --laser_listen [channel id 1,channel id 2, ... channel id N]

title: Beam command line (CLI) guide
description: The "official" Beam command line reference guide!

children.value: The command line is the most reliable method of using Beam wallets and certain features (Registering CAs, Lightning Payments, Beam Shaders) can only perform on the command line. Available for macOS, Windows, and Linux.

Due to Beam's LelantusMW protocols, the private keys of Beam wallets record the user's UTXO balance on the blockchain, while transaction histories, addresses, and other wallet metadata are stored locally on each device.
Beam allows users to run a full node and interact with it via the command line.
This section uses Linux and macOS commands; Windows users, please substitute
and Windows Command Prompts where necessary.
To create a new wallet, enter the following command:
command will ask users to create a wallet password:
Create a strong wallet password and keep your password secret! Anyone who has your wallet password will have access to your funds! Wallet passwords protect your
files that store all your crucial wallet metadata.
After creating your wallet password, the
command output should resemble the following:

$ ./beam-wallet init

        Print or write down the phrase to keep it in a safe or in a locked vault.

Keep your seed phrase secret, and never share your seed phrase with anyone!
{% endhint %}

Your seed phrase is the only way you (or anybody) can access your funds. Your seed phrase is not linked to your email or phone number. If you forget your wallet password or lose your device, the only way to restore your wallet is through your seed phrase!

Please do not write your seed phrase down electronically, take a screenshot or store it anywhere vulnerable to cyber attacks. Pen and paper are unhackable and recommended. Make multiple copies of your seed phrase and store them somewhere safe.
Restoring CLI wallet from seed phrase
Restoring Beam coins from an old wallet seed phrase requires users to run their own node and
To begin restoring your CLI wallet, first create a new wallet by entering the following command:

props.code: ./beam-wallet restore --seed_phrase=<semicolon separated list of 12 seed phrase words>;

children.value: ./beam-wallet restore --seed_phrase=<semicolon separated list of 12 seed phrase words>;
from your Beam wallet. Enter the following command:
Now that you have exported the
, you can run your own node by entering the following command:

props.code: ./beam-node --peer=<ip and port of peer node> --key_owner=<owner key exported from the wallet>

Once the node has synchronized, connect your wallet to the node and update your wallet database by entering the following command:

Beam wallets create a new wallet address for every transaction, It is possible however, to extend the expiration (24 hours) for an old address.
Extending the expiration date for a single wallet address
To extend your wallet address expiration date, enter the following command:
Extending the expiration for all addresses in your Beam wallet
To extend your wallets existing addresses, use the previous command, omitting the
Wallet addresses provided users with three different expiration date options:
: address expiration date will never expire.
: wallet address expiration date will extend for an additional 24 hours before expiring.
: the wallet address will be expire immediately and will no longer be usable.

If you have previously created a Beam wallet, you can recover your funds by restoring your wallet from your 12-word seed phrase. However, your wallet data (transaction history, contacts, addresses) is always stored locally onto your

title: Using Beam smart contracts with CLI Wallet

children.value: Using Beam smart contracts with CLI Wallet
Beam compatible binaries are available for
Advanced users that wish to build Beam directly from our source code can see this
for a more detailed run down.

We strongly recommend for all users, casual and hardcore, that you download the node, CLI wallet in addition to the Desktop wallet. The application for smart contracts is in its infancy, with many unique and helpful smart contracts lacking a graphical interface, meaning they are only available through the Command-Line.
Building out your node and operating the CLI wallet will keep you at the forefront of all the latest and coolest features that Beam has to offer. It is a simple process that only takes a minute.
Beam Smart Contracts deploy via an application called
. Beam Shaders are small (or not so small) programs compatible with several different programming languages before being compiled as a
file since Beam Virtual Machine (BVM) runs on WebAssembly.
No coding experience is necessary; several Beam Shader applications are ready and available to
Select from the list of Beam Shader apps and get into some 'shady business!'
As seen from the above example, there are several app folders, i.e., '
,' and inside each folder will be a list of files that will resemble the following:
The reason for that is that each application comes in two parts. The first is the contract deployed to the blockchain (
) and the second allows the wallet to interact with the contract (
folder with the subfolder with specific apps like
Now let's see how we can run some apps!
contract allows users to withdraw or deposit small amounts of Beam coins.
To view all the available contract commands, enter this command:

./beam-wallet shader --shader_app_file shaders/faucet/app.wasm -n 127.0.0.1:8501

The founding mission behind Beam was to make the Beam ecosystem as decentralized as possible. The introduction of the BeamX DAO is another step towards realizing that founding mission. The BeamX DAO empowers BeamX stakeholders with total control over the governance protocol.
Stakeholders have voting power on every aspect of the ecosystem through the BeamX token.
BeamX stakeholders are encouraged to vote with the personal voting selection, identity, and financial holdings will all remain private.
BeamX has a 100M total supply with a 4-year emission schedule. Earn BeamX tokens by staking your Beam coins.
